ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was:
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I benefitted the most from the mock negotiations as I have no prior experience.
Understanding of international climate policy. Negotiating. Diplomacy.
I learned about the history of climate change negotiations and agreements. The mock negotiation was quite helpful, and it would have been interesting to do multiple ones to see how to improve.
I learned about how negotiations are conducted and the various strategies associated with the negotiation process.
Understanding how COP negotiations worked in practice.
I learned about historic multilateral climate agreements, negotiating climate agreements, and topics for COP 25.

Great overlook at the history of international climate change negotiations. The course also teaches you how international agreements have evolved and changed over time. Professor Biniaz does a great job at providing this infomation and giving students annecdotal information of what happens behind the scenes.
Understanding the makeup of climate agreements and how negotiations work
History of climate change negotiations Practical knowledge about navigating international negotiations Problem solving during negotiations
General understanding of the history of Climate Change Negotiations and how it has evolved over the years

How international climate negotiations came to be, and how they work. The nuance that comes from the language of the agreements and different tactics to get there. Very interesting to learn about diplomacy through this lens.
I learned about the history, strengths, and weaknesses of climate change agreements. I also learned about and practiced various tactics of climate change negotiations.
This course provides a fantastic review of the UNFCCC and the history of climate change negotiations.

narratives.question_text: How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations?
comments: As expected
Better than expected.
I learned a decent amount, but I think I would have learned more if I had found the class time to be more engaging or interactive.
I expected the material to be presented in a more interactive style. However, it felt like at times we were just being lectured at, with limited discussion.
Did not have very high expectations but it was OK.
The class met my expectations very well.
Class met all my expectations of what I expect to learn from it.
extremely well
Aligned very well.
well
Yes - expected to learn tools and diplomacy insights to have a solid foundation for attending COP and this course did just that.
Yes, this course exceeded my expectations. This was the most fascinating course that I took this semester.
Very well.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
comments: Clearer instructions on assignments would be beneficial.
N/A
The class would have benefited from more discussion-based experiences as opposed to just long lectures.
I really enjoyed the mock negotiations. I believe the weakest part was limited opportunities to discuss how issues had originally been raised by various countries.
Have a perspective of how things work in reality; negotiations were exactly as seen in class.
I really enjoyed Sue's method of lecturing.
Professor Biniaz has so much experience and it was really great to hear her take on climate negotiations. For a one credit course, there was a lot to be learn from the class
Interesting content but content delivery could be improved by preparing lecture slides instead of projecting sections of assigned readings on screens
Sue is very engaging when she speaks, even when it's from a chair on stage. She adds a wit and humor to the topic that makes it easy to follow.

I found this course interesting and practical. I especially appreciated being able to apply the tactics we learned in class to the negotiations exercise, which helped to prepare students for COP. I think it could be improved by providing feedback on assignments and facilitating a little more student engagement during lectures.

This is a very balanced 1 credit course. The readings / homework are the right length and the lectures are fantastic. Even though the course is pass/fail, I think it could be improved by receiving feedback on the written assignment and mock negotiation.

narratives.question_text: What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class?
comments: Work with classmates - it makes understanding easier.
Go to COP!

You will get out of it what you put into it. It was very cool to have the opportunity to learn from Professor Biniaz, but the lectures can be challenging to get through late on Mondays when the semester is in full force.
This is an interesting course with a low workload.
It is a great class to take if you are interested in international climate negotiations (even if you are not planning on going to COP).
If you are planning to go to COP, this course is definitely useful preparation
it's a must if you're going to cop
If you are interested in climate negotiations, global climate governance, or multilateralism, definitely take this course!

This class taught by Sue Biniaz is a unique opportunity to learn about the climate change negotiations from someone who has been a part of the process for decades. I highly recomment taking this course.
